cdata.constitutionalAuthorityStatementText: [Congressional Record Volume 170, Number 64 (Monday, April 15, 2024)][House]From the Congressional Record Online through the Government Publishing Office [www.gpo.gov]By Ms. NORTON:H.R. 8008.Congress has the power to enact this legislation pursuantto the following:Clause 18 of Section 8 of Article I of the ConstitutionThe single subject of this legislation is:This bill would award a posthumous Congressional Gold Medalto the 13 African Americans who became the first AfricanAmerican commissioned and warrant officers in the UnitedStates Navy.[Page H2398]

item.text: Referred to the Committee on Financial Services, and in addition to the Committee on House Administration, for a period to be subsequently determined by the Speaker, in each case for consideration of such provisions as fall within the jurisdiction of the committee concerned.

Referred to the Committee on Financial Services, and in addition to the Committee on House Administration, for a period to be subsequently determined by the Speaker, in each case for consideration of such provisions as fall within the jurisdiction of the committee concerned.
Sponsor introductory remarks on measure. (CR E349)

cdata.text:
Golden Thirteen Congressional Gold Medal Act

This bill provides for the posthumous award of a Congressional Gold Medal to the Golden Thirteen (i.e., members of the first officer training course for African Americans in the U.S. Navy), in recognition of their contributions to the country.

bill.title: Golden Thirteen Congressional Gold Medal Act

item.title: Golden Thirteen Congressional Gold Medal Act
Golden Thirteen Congressional Gold Medal Act
To award posthumously a Congressional Gold Medal to the Golden Thirteen, in recognition of their contributions to the Nation.

latestAction.text: Referred to the Committee on Financial Services, and in addition to the Committee on House Administration, for a period to be subsequently determined by the Speaker, in each case for consideration of such provisions as fall within the jurisdiction of the committee concerned.

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
